segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to the annual DEFCON convention. This meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas, Nevada from July 9th through the 11th, 1999.
This is videotape number 43. Text files, G-files, and log files. Remembering the 1980s through ASCII.
I guess I'll begin talking. You all know this is text files of the 1980s.
Should I talk with this, or? Yeah, okay. Hey, we're in the hallway. You're listening to an incredible speech by a master of ceremonies.
Oh, it's not going to work. Okay. Anyone want to figure out which of these makes this stop feedbacking?
Either one or the other one. Do you want another one? Turn either one off.
Yeah, now we're going to feedback off of each other.
They did the schedule around. They didn't need to tell anybody, and that's fine, too.
My name's Jason Scott. A lot of people know me, well, people who do care, know me as the sysop of the works BBS, which was a text file BBS from, well, there's two works.
There was 1986 to 1988, when my dad found the big phone bill, and then 1989 until about 1996, it was run by a kid named Dave Ferret, who screwed the code up so bad.
And he ran, and that's when I think most people started to learn about, that's when it became a CDC board, and I was just kind of sysop emeritus.
Before that, there was a golden age of about 1982 to about 1986-87, where I was known as the slipped disk.
And I can see by the sea of faces, I was forefront in your lives.
But right now, the main project I do besides my regular job is working on a site called textfiles.com, which I hope some of you have browsed.
If not, basically what I've been working on is I'm trying to collect thousands and thousands of text files from the 1980s BBS scene,
and assemble them in a somewhat cohesive manner, separated by somewhat arbitrary topics, with descriptions that will cause you to want to get to them.
And it's going along pretty well, and I said, what the heck, I'm going to speak at DEF CON about it, maybe I can get some more people who are interested in it.
And so today I'll be talking mostly a little bit about the site, and a little bit of reminiscing, and a little bit about why I really got into the whole business.
I'm one of these guys who is really anal, which you'd find out if you went to the site.
And so I have my speech kind of out in front of me, so I'm one of these guys who's going to keep looking down.
I'm sorry about that, but I'll try to make eye contact as much as I can.
So just to get an idea, to me there's a difference between having a computer and having a computer with a modem.
It makes a big difference.
So I just want to call out a year, and go back down, and just hold up your hand if you had a computer with a modem in that year,
and we'll just go back, and I'm sure we're going to get some low numbers here.
But anyway, 1995, who had a modem?
Okay.
1994, okay, let's get down.
1990, okay.
1988, alright, more people came in, 1988.
1985, okay, now we're starting to, okay.
1982, alright, okay.
And a couple people apparently were on 8BBS.
79, what's this, okay, there you go, okay.
Why connected to a UNIX server, considering a computer?
Well, I mean, it's a computer, but it's not, it's out of my scope, you know.
In other words, for me what I'm talking about are like, you're a kid or a guy, you got a modem, you log in.
But yeah, I mean, basically if you dial in, because I mean, what I'm dealing with here are dial-ins.
Well, that's not entirely true, and sometimes you serve.
I didn't pay for it.
I used to rant about that, $10 a freaking hour, and more if it was $1,200 bought, thank you.
So I used to go on, I used to go download all of Moira's stuff, download all the Encyclopedia, that was a real jerk.
Anyway, so basically some people might wonder, maybe some, why I got into textfiles.com.
Basically what happened was a while ago, you know, I was kind of sitting around on my computer,
I'm one of these guys who just kind of browses randomly for hours on end,
and I suddenly wondered, you know, whatever happened to some of those old guys I was in,
you know, I used to know, and all the BBSs that I knew,
hey, I bet there's some really great site out there, and I can learn all about what happened and everything.
So, you know, booted up AltaVista, stuck in Sherwood Forest 2, stuck in the history of K-Cool Dudes,
stuck in stuff about Count Nibble, and to my surprise, there was like nothing.
There was just this dearth. Occasionally there'd be a little frack magazine mention of somebody,
but all in all, it was like there was nothing. I was just astounded.
There was absolutely nothing. So I went back to my dad's house, grabbed my old text file collection,
and I started kind of building things up from there.
And, you know, right now I'm sitting at about 18,000 text files are online.
I've got 45,000 left to look at, and that's that I know of.
There's actually a few people giving me CD-ROMs and 50 meg archives by mail,
basically for me to sort through.
And so it's actually, I've pretty much got my year set.
I don't think I'll be doing much else this year, because it's really important to me.
And actually, you know, oh, he's just saying hi.
Hello! Hello!
A lot of people might say, great, so you looked up Sherwood Forest 2 and you got nothing.
Why didn't you just go back to Slashdot and be done with it?
And for me, there was actually three main reasons why.
Number one, I'm really into subcultures.
I think subcultures are really fascinating things, all the different people.
You have the people who know what they're doing, the people who don't know what they're doing, the battles.
In the 1980s, especially, and even now in the 90s, there was this very special time that pretty much
a vast majority of how this subculture communicated is digital and was saved.
And if you know where to find it, if you get it from, you know, garage.
I mean, there's kids now, people like me and stuff.
You know, a stack of five and a quarter inch floppies.
In fact, actually, I brought one.
Just in case, in case anyone has never seen one of these, because they kind of phased them out.
Look at it, it's flat and it's weird and it's floppy, it's a floppy disk.
And note that I also have the second notch, because I wanted it to be double-sided.
That was $143K a side on an Apple II.
Actually, more if you took out the...
I did not pay the $45 for the disk density increaser that they sold in the back where you go,
ka-chunk, great, there's some guy in office supply who's living in,
a guy from the office supply business living in Aruba now.
But anyway, yeah, I just went back and grabbed all my old stuff and put it up.
And, you know, a lot of people have that and a lot of people do have this past.
So that was one reason.
The other is that I really like to read.
I really like reading.
I like just picking up lots of books and just reading them all.
And for me, with the text files, I'm reading all this...
Some of this stuff is really fascinating.
And yeah, some of it's really badly spelled and boring.
But even then, when it's a rant by some kid,
he's 13 and he's talking about he's the master of the universe,
and this other kid, he sucks.
All he ever uses is a Commodore 64.
He is a dork.
I hate him.
Don't pay attention to him.
He's not elite.
You know, you can't buy that kind of drama.
So I actually do honestly enjoy this stuff.
I'm not...
This isn't a means to an end.
It is the end for me.
I mean, it's basically what I like.
And the third one, which is actually the more emotional one,
is that it is my childhood.
I was born in 1970.
And my father gave me my first computer.
It was a Commodore PET, which I actually still own.
Rockin' 8K of memory.
Yeah.
Cassette drive and a little 5-inch screen that's kind of not happy now.
The IEEE port.
The IEEE port, yes, which I never got to use
because I had no idea what the hell that thing was.
It was just a thing.
But you could flip it up like a car
and put a little car hood thing.
And the thing was flipped up and there's your board that you can't do anything
because you're a foolish kid.
And then we moved up to an IBM PC XT
with a 2400 baud internal modem,
which Dad took from work.
Not bad for you, too.
It was good.
I was Mr. Elite Boy.
People forget the baud wars.
People forget these...
People, back when it was like, dude, we're 2400 only.
Well, no, the thing was 2400 only.
They weren't going to let the riffraff with the 300 baud acoustic modems on.
They wanted it 2400.
You wanted to get those couple dozen characters a little quicker.
Especially good for wares.
I think that continued up.
I don't know if it actually made it up to 28A,
but it definitely made it up to 19-2
that you had 19-2 only trading boards.
I think after that, pretty much everyone had it.
So it really wasn't that elite.
You raising your hand for something?
No.
You said 28A did, but that's not what you did.
It did happen for a while.
Good.
I like being corrected, because I'm being a historian.
And if I sit there and go, yeah, it was this.
If I read it out of Stephen Levy's Hackers or something,
and it's just kind of sitting in my mind,
and it's complete crap, I want to know.
That's very important to me,
because if I'm speaking from a position of authority on that file,
I don't want people who weren't there to look at it and think,
that's the way things were if I'm doing it wrong.
I really don't like, I like being corrected.
So correct me if you go, no, that's not the way it was.
I've actually had several screaming phone calls that way.
But, yeah, from about 82, I was running a PCXT.
Hey there.
How did HST become known?
I missed that, but I do know what you're talking about.
I did see it mentioned on things.
16.88 HST, that was the hot shit.
Yeah, see, that's the thing.
That's the funny part.
You have all these people who are arguing
because they have the most badass transport protocol on their system.
And you, forget you.
You.
You?
Mm-hmm.
So.
You?
You.
Oh, I, well, that's the thing.
I mean, I don't know.
But I mean, I, okay.
Yeah, so what I call the milestone of history there is that people,
when people speak from, basically from a position of authority
and they're speaking about this is the way it was,
especially in a published medium,
I don't like the idea of someone being turned off.
They read five, six files, and they're like, you know,
they read my descriptions, like this guy has no clue.
And I like to track people down.
A lot of people from that time have come to me,
and I've said, is this how it was?
I'm just an interviewing guy,
hopefully asking them questions that most of them really didn't expect to be asked,
which is kind of nice.
Most of them are like, oh, that's the old stuff.
So just to clarify, when you say text file,
especially to people who were born in, you know, 85 and so on,
who like are here now, you say text file.
They're like, yeah, great, what?
What's a text file?
Who cares?
It's not a binary file.
That's great.
So I just wanted to find what a text file was as I see it.
The way I see it, when BBSs were around,
you had BBS messages on something that other people said.
And you had files.
You could upload and download binary and text files.
And some people had facts.
Granted, many of them are legal.
But, you know, they had facts or stories or something
that they thought was more important than the board they were on particularly.
And they had something they wanted to pass on.
Way down in the Apple sub-board somewhere,
it was some file, some hack, some story, some exploit
that would basically, you know, had to get out there.
So they would write it as a text file, put it up into the file section,
and people would download it.
And so when I say a text file, I'm talking about,
and so you get into the classic text file, which I want to mention.
A lot of people call me old school.
And I don't particularly like the term
because people seem to use it for everything that they weren't a part of.
And I'll go on, you know, I'm browsing a lot of sites,
and people will go, dude, I remember old school.
Ninety-two.
Back when it was just us and the VGA cards.
And, you know, and they're being honest.
I mean, you know, that's seven years ago.
Of course it's old school to them.
Somebody suggested classic.
So I don't know, maybe I'll use classic from now on
and say I was a classic hacker.
But once again, then you get guys from the 60s calling me an embryo,
and that's about that.
But, you know, for me the classic text file,
I don't have any slides, but if you can imagine,
basically if you had a text file,
the classic G file,
and G file, as far as I can determine,
comes from Apple software that had general files
where you could download, you know,
and they would stick all their text files
into the general file section,
and everyone started calling them G files,
into T files,
and then people started adding Zs at the end,
and I was like, oh, what the hell.
But for the standard text file,
you know, you download it off the Defcon VBS,
you know, it's 64, it's a 64K Apple.
I actually have a VBS ad where the guy proudly claims
he's got an Apple II, 48K,
got the 80 column card in,
he's got two Apple II disks
with Maxell diskettes.
This is part of his system features,
is I'm using Maxell diskettes in the disk drive.
So you're on the Defcon VBS,
and of course you just want to get on,
so of course you're constantly breaking into chat,
and Dark Tangent gets up from watching war games
and lets you on.
And you go right to the file section,
through the VBS section,
there's just going to be more kids,
so you go right to the file section,
you get this big, you download one,
How to Hack Defcon,
and it's got a big square at the top,
it's got this big text graphic square
made of equal signs and dashes,
and stars and stuff,
and it says, How to do it by Nightwing,
or you know,
these incredible names that kids used to come up with.
The Mad Phone Man,
Skate the Skinhead,
Black Agent 003,
The Knights of Fargo 4A.
I heard the reason that they were called that,
and this may be crap,
but this is one of those stories that kind of goes up,
I'd love to be corrected.
Supposedly the Fargo 4A group
were a group of phone freaks
who one day connected to
Fargo's main center
for their directory assistance operators
on Alliance Teleconference,
which I'm sure they didn't pay for,
and using a bunch of keyboards,
so just talking on the phone like this,
and saying, look, we're over at this office,
and we're doing this, and it's very important,
and just social engineering these people,
they convinced them that it was a test day,
and that, oh, the other center
will be taking over for the day,
so we wish for you to go home,
because we have to do some testing
on your equipment, and they did it.
Supposedly that's what it was,
they were blown away, they got them all to leave
for like a few hours, and there was no directory assistance
in Fargo,
because they were all gone home.
Anyway, that's more about BIOC later.
So yeah, you have the big ol' huge
big ol' huge square
with the text graphics,
and then right underneath it, the disclaimer.
And you have the classic disclaimer,
the author will not take any
informational purposes, that's a little bit
big for these kids, the author will not
the author will take no responsibility
for this file, it was like boilerplate.
Now I don't know of any cases
where that ever came into play, I mean,
maybe I missed one, oh, do you know of one?
The method of editing Calc 2
in one of the earlier crack issues
caused a bit of a stir.
But I mean,
what I'm saying is, yeah?
Deb Swingey
actually
there was a textbook
on his work,
Anarchy for Fun and Profit.
Yes.
And his disclaimer said that
he actually took responsibility
for everything that was done by the man.
Right.
He never got in trouble.
He's very sad about it, actually.
He and I are very old friends, he was a sysop on the works.
And he's actually rather ashamed of that file.
And he really doesn't want it to get out.
And so it's really been a big issue for me
because I really don't want
to be the role of censor, I hate that.
I hate going on to a place
and it's like, here's a file
but we're showing it for you
for historical purposes but we can't show you
what's in it because it's, you know,
you won't be able to handle the ingredient list.
You know?
And I just, I hate being that.
It's just not the role I like.
In terms of that one, I do know that DeathVeggie
personally never got any problems
but that a lot of other people
were problematic, including a Hartford
BBS operator who went to jail
for a short period of time
because of an overzealous Hartford prosecutor
who said,
and dragged him on over that text file.
And DeathVeggie called him in jail
and said, I'm really sorry.
Because by that time, our BBS, the works BBS
had deleted the file.
We'd deleted it long before because he'd looked at it
and said, this is stupid.
What a stupid file to have up. So he got rid of it.
And I didn't even know about that.
You had a question, sir?
Oh, what were you saying?
I have all the FRACs
that I know of.
Oh, the FRAC text file
and log archive.
Are you speaking
of the Phoenix Project?
The LOD Phoenix Project.
Well,
I have currently
the three 200k
text files,
the 200k log file
examples that they did.
I ran into Mr. Bloodaxe
yesterday and had a nice chat with him.
And he said, wow, you're doing really good work.
Do you want all of them?
And I said, yes, I would like all of them.
So hopefully he'll give them to me.
Because he said,
it's been long enough. The product is dead.
Let's just give it out.
And so, yeah,
believe it or not, I get really excited
about stuff like that.
I'm really like an archaeologist.
Like,
recently, about two months ago,
I was kind of wandering around
in some place called the Chavin
BBS, Chavin.com.
In their FTP section, they had Apple Docs.
They had a lot.
And I couldn't get them down. There was like some weird thing.
I talked to the guy who was on
one of their little MUDs they had.
And he said, oh, let me give them to you.
And I had about 20
soft docs.
Just to mention, soft docs are basically
text files that were transcriptions
of manuals. So when you pirated something,
you also included the soft docs
so you know you press control E to make the
troll fire.
And
suddenly I went from 20 to having
700. Like cat fur
docs and 80 docs
and everything. And I was excited.
It was 2 in the morning. I was supposed to go home.
I'm not going to work the next day. I'm like, no.
I'm going to stay here. I'm going to stay up all night.
Totally screw up my schedule. I'm going to
go and make all these text files go up.
And I had forgotten. That's a lot of what
it was for me back in the 80s. A lot of it was like
I'm on the South Pole.
They have so much bomb shit.
I'm going to take it all.
It wasn't even to read or trade.
It was just I'm going to get all the files.
So, yeah.
After the disclaimer, then you had the stuff.
At the bottom, there were 6 billion greets.
I just wanted to mention that as well.
Greets out to this. Call this BBS.
They rock. They've got the stuff.
That actually goes on now quite a bit.
That standard thing.
When I say text file, that's what I'm talking about.
I'm not talking about source code or stuff.
Although, now
I do ask for BBS messages
and log files and
things like that for historical purposes.
So, unfortunately, textfiles.com
has really expanded in its
admission to the point now that
I'm going to probably need a staff.
What's up?
Oh, sure.
The shirt?
No, it's okay. It weeds out
the unfaithful ones.
I can see who will sell me out for this shirt.
I'll buy the tape. It'll be okay.
So, yeah.
Historically,
let's see if you go
with my theory.
I was trying to find the original text file.
What's the original text file?
You have an idea?
My theory?
This book is called
Steal This Book.
It was written by a gentleman
named Abby Hoffman
who also went by the name Barry Fried
when he was running from the government
for several years before he let himself in.
The book is basically a call to smash the state.
It's basically a list of
ways to rip off the system.
Rip off the bell. Rip off telephones.
Rip off supermarkets.
Get printed for free.
Go out and do stuff.
Abby was a really funny guy.
This was a Chicago 7 dude who
brought that pig in.
He always
mentions in the book that
there are people who know
theater without politics or politics without theater
are doomed in both.
That shows in a lot of his stuff.
He has this real
light attitude
about the whole thing.
Hey, we're going to smash the system. Yay.
Like I said, a lot of people
think Abby makes them cringe and
whore and stuff, but interestingly
enough, Abby was part of a
small part of a little
zine called the Youth International
Party Line, which was a
newsletter of the Yippies.
The Youth International Party.
It was basically very political
but it also had a lot of things on how to rip off
the phone company. A big thing back then
was the war tax that
the phone company
was actually taking
an extra little tax to pay for
I think it was the Vietnam War. It might have been a different war.
And then they're blinded
and it didn't go away.
And everyone was like,
ah, we will get free
phone service because of this.
You actually see a lot
of that. You see that stuff with like TouchTone
and they still charge for TouchTone even though
it's cost them less to have
TouchTone.
Huh?
Right. They charge for
stuff that helps
them. But anyway, so
this Youth International Party Line about
a lot of the stuff was basically
these text files on it
about how to do different things. The phone code
every year. Hey, let's get the phone code out.
And, um,
yes. I'm so sorry. No, it's okay.
One other piece of business.
If anyone is interested in working for the NSA
several people have asked.
Several people are afraid to give out their information.
Please come see me
at some point during the convention. I will make sure
you are taken care of.
The best part about working for the NSA
is you just think you want to.
They don't come to you.
Oh, they're here.
Thank you.
Here's my resume. We know.
Um, anyway,
so he went from Hipple and
Al Bell, who was his co-editor, said,
you know, let's really go for the technical side.
And Addy was like, no, let's go with the political side.
So Al Bell broke off and started TAP,
the Technological Assistance Program.
And some people are like, have you heard of TAP?
Is there a TAP?

You haven't heard of TAP?
Um, there's a guy named The Fixer,
freaking.iscool.net.
Um, and he
has digitized all the issues
of Hipple and TAP and put them on a CD-ROM
for like ten bucks
with like five hundred text files,
actually about a thousand text files on it.
Really nice deal.
Um, I tried to get him to come,
but he wouldn't come.
It's a really fascinating, fascinating
magazine.
It really had a really good sense of humor
that was kind of duplicated in 2600.
To me, see, 2600
were those young, snotty upstarts
that were trying to push off TAP.
And TAP had a whole problem
with a fire.
And the editor at the time,
I think it was Tom Edison at the time,
when it was Cheshire Catalyst,
basically said,
okay, I think we're done here. My apartment got burned down.
And so, you know,
for me, I'm claiming
Mr. Hoffman is the father of the text file.
Um, we'll see if that
holds up over time.
Um,
so, um,
I don't know why, when I was a kid,
I really wanted text files only.
I think the reason why was because I had a PC
and a lot of the boards were Apple, so I didn't have any use for these wares.
I didn't have any use for the Commodore boards.
I was one of those kids who would get the BBS list
and just go down it sequentially.
You know, oh, this board, it's a
police board, they're talking about something,
okay, I'm on. You know,
this board is Unix, this board is some

Yeah?
I got a question. Are you posting, are any of you
posting files for any different characters?
It's like a C64 file.
The closest I have, that's,
that's, yeah, you're starting to get to these
basic, basic architectural problems
I've been running into.
Right now, all of my files are ASCII,
except
I have a lot of IBM
files with that idiotic
second 128 characters
with the little lines and the little stuff

screw everyone else. And
I have ANSI files, because I had ANSI
files.

I don't have any ANSI music,
I don't have any,
I don't have any of those, and I, you know,
I feel, I really feel like
it's outside my area.
I'm so close, but I'm,
What about a TASCII?
A TASCII?
A TASCII?
I haven't had to think about that
forever. That's the one that had Bob in it, didn't it?
That was the ST?
Yeah, which I don't have. Like, again,
I start to feel after a while like the record store
with the computer software, and you got the
kid with the six piercings, he's like, yeah, I guess
it's compatible. You know?
After a while, I'm like, I can't look at it
even, you know? I can look at ANSI, and I can
look at the IBM graphics, and I can't look at the other stuff.
I don't have anything there. I'm sure eventually we'll have the
textfiles.com testing lab. What?
If it's been transferred to ASCII,
I got my hands on it. Because I get a lot
of my stuff from outside. So,
if somebody took it and took the time to do that,
like the Apple docs, this guy had it on a
Unix box, so he took them from
a whole ton of Apple disks. He did that
conversion work, and I was benefiting
off that conversion work and thanking him for it.
So, you know,
that's about as close as I get.
But, yeah,
so basically, as far as I can tell, I was just taking text
files because it was the one thing I could take. And after a while,
I just really started digging them. And I had
files and files, and interestingly
enough, back when I was 13, every one I
put them on was called The Works. It was a
The Works, this kind of text file. The Works, this kind of
text file, because I always wanted to run a board called The Works.
And it was actually
only three or four years later that I
actually ran one.
So, just to mention what some of
those VBSs were, I'm just going to grab three.
Because, I mean, I called hundreds and hundreds.
Some of them just sank into obscurity
after seconds after I went on them.
Some of them, you know, I was on for years and
years and I absolutely loved.
First VBS, you never forget
the first VBS you were co-SysOp on,
when the guy gave you co-SysOp access and you
were helping to run the show.
And for me, it was a place called The Restaurant at the
End of the Universe. Very original name.
And it was run by a gentleman named
Mr. IO, who one day
named the place to
Outland, and he named himself The Outland.
And he was a member of a text file writing group called
The Neon Knights, slash
Metal Communications, who were a
group of metalheads.
And I was at his house once,
he was in New Jersey, and I was at his house once
and the Blade and the Metallian came
over. And these kids,
and, you know, I grew
up in Westchester, New
